title: Bayesian Theory of Mind
text: Bayesian Theory of Mind models how agents infer others’ hidden mental states from observable actions.

title: Bayesian Theory of Mind
text:
Bayes’ Rule
We update a hypothesis \(H\) about an agent’s intention after seeing data \(D\) via Bayes’ rule:
\[
P(H \mid D) = \frac{P(D \mid H) P(H)}{P(D)}.
\]
For example, suppose a robot infers whether a person wants tea (\(H\)) after watching them fill a kettle (\(D\)). With prior belief \(P(H)=0.3\), likelihood \(P(D\mid H)=0.8\), and marginal \(P(D)=0.41\), the posterior is computed below.
prior = 0.3
likelihood = 0.8
evidence = 0.41
posterior = likelihood * prior / evidence
posterior

title: Bayesian Theory of Mind
text:
Sequential Updates
Bayesian agents can repeatedly incorporate new evidence. The snippet below simulates three observations and prints the updated belief after each.
import numpy as np

prior = 0.5
data = [0.9, 0.7, 0.2]
for likelihood in data:
    prior = likelihood * prior / (likelihood * prior + (1 - likelihood) * (1 - prior))
    print(prior)
These simple calculations demonstrate how Bayesian reasoning can support a theory of mind in artificial agents.
